questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of worsening right calf and heel pain. The pain started suddenly during a run that was part of an exercise program for weight loss, which he started 4 weeks ago. Since the onset of pain, he has mainly stayed at home to rest his leg. He has hypertension and chronic bacterial prostatitis. He drinks one to two beers daily and does not smoke cigarettes. His medications are hydrochlorothiazide and levofloxacin. One week ago, he returned from a business trip to Australia. He is 183 cm (6 ft 0 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the right leg shows swelling and tenderness to palpation of the posterior distal calf and the posterior heel. There is no plantar flexion when squeezing the calf while the patient is in the prone position. Compression of the medial and lateral aspects of the heel does not elicit pain. Examination of the left leg shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Retrocalcaneal bursitis commonly manifests with pain and swelling in the region of the Achilles tendon insertion and is associated with increased age, obesity, and sudden increase in physical activity. However, physical examination usually shows localized tenderness with compression of the soft tissue behind the Achilles tendon superior to the calcaneus, not tenderness of the posterior distal calf and the posterior heel. Furthermore, Thompson test is typically normal in patients with retrocalcaneal bursitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) commonly manifests with unilateral swelling and tenderness of the calf and occurs most frequently after long periods of immobilization (e.g., long-distance flights). However, a sudden onset of symptoms with physical activity is uncommon in DVT. Furthermore, this patient has no other signs of DVT (e.g., warmth, erythema, dilated veins). Finally, physical examination does not typically elicit pain in the heel, and Thompson test is usually normal.

C) CORRECT:

Achilles tendon rupture commonly manifests with acute, severe pain during strenuous activity, calf tenderness, calf swelling, and abnormal Thompson test. A loud snapping sound is a hallmark of this condition, although it does not occur in every patient. Risk factors for Achilles tendon rupture include male sex, advanced age, obesity, a sudden increase in exercise intensity, and the use of fluoroquinolones. Although rupture of the Achilles tendon is usually a clinical diagnosis, ultrasonography and MRI might be used to confirm the diagnosis. Conservative management of Achilles tendon rupture includes icing, analgesics (e.g., with NSAIDs), immobilization, and rest, while surgical options include an open or percutaneous tendon repair. The choice between conservative therapy and surgical therapy depends largely on comorbidities, age, and activity level.
Image Description:

There is a loss of definition of the left Achilles tendon and an inability to plantar flex the left foot (right leg is shown for comparison).

D) INCORRECT:

Calcaneal apophysitis commonly manifests with unilateral or bilateral heel pain during strenuous physical activity and occurs most frequently in male individuals and people with obesity. It is, however, more common in adolescents than in adults, with a peak incidence age of 8–12 years. Furthermore, physical examination usually elicits pain with compression of the heel, not the distal calf, and Thompson test is typically normal.

E) INCORRECT:

Calcaneal stress fracture commonly manifests with heel pain and is caused by poor technique or an increase in exercise load or frequency. The pain typically worsens during physical activity and subsides with rest. However, physical examination usually shows tenderness along the medial and lateral walls of the posterior calcaneus, not tenderness of the posterior distal calf and the posterior heel. Furthermore, Thompson test is typically normal.
questions.hint: The lack of passive plantar flexion with calf squeeze indicates an abnormal Thompson test.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute posterior calf pain. The pain began during a tennis game (part of a new exercise routine), when he lunged to hit the ball. He felt as though he had been kicked in the back of the leg, even though there was no one behind him. His medical history is unremarkable, other than obesity and a recent episode of sinusitis for which he received levofloxacin.
He is able to walk but has tenderness to palpation about 2 to 3 cm above the calcaneal insertion site on the affected leg. Compression of the gastrocnemius muscle while the patient is in a prone position does not produce plantar flexion on the affected side but does so on the contralateral side.
A radiograph of the ankle is negative for fracture but reveals a calcaneal heel spur.
Which one of the following initial management approaches is best for this patient?

choices.text: Ice and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug therapy
Ice, analgesics, immobilization, and an orthopedics consultation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcaneal bursitis, which could be treated with a glucocorticoid injection, would cause pain and tenderness near the Achilles tendon, but it would not be associated with a positive Thompson test.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy is not appropriate for an acute tendon rupture.

C) INCORRECT:

Ice plus nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug therapy would be an appropriate treatment option for Achilles tendinitis without evidence of tear. It would also be appropriate for plantar fasciitis, which would manifest as pain in the plantar region of the sole of the foot.

D) INCORRECT:

CT of the heel would be appropriate for a suspected calcaneal fracture but is not helpful or required in the evaluation of an acute Achilles tendon rupture.

E) CORRECT:

Older age, male gender, obesity, and recent fluoroquinolone use are all risk factors for Achilles tendinopathy or tendon rupture. A patient may be able to walk in spite of rupture. Absence of plantar flexion upon compression of the gastrocnemius muscle while the patient is in the prone position (Thompson test) has high sensitivity and specificity for detecting a clinically significant tear of the Achilles tendon. In addition to recommending ice, analgesics, and immobilization of the ankle in plantar flexion, the treating clinician should obtain an orthopedics consultation for consideration of surgical repair.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management for Achilles tendon rupture includes ice, analgesics, immobilization with the ankle in plantar flexion, and an orthopedics consultation.
Image Description:

In a healthy individual, squeezing the calf (i.e., the gastrocnemius muscle) results in passive plantar flexion of the foot. Passive plantar flexion is absent in an Achilles tendon rupture.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with acute posterior ankle pain after landing awkwardly during a recreational basketball game. He describes hearing a “pop” and now has difficulty walking. Examination shows calf swelling and a palpable gap in the Achilles tendon. The Thompson test is positive. X-ray of the ankle is normal. After providing analgesia, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: MRI to determine extent of rupture
Immobilization in plantar flexion with orthopedic referral
Weight-bearing as tolerated with physical therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While MRI can distinguish partial from complete tears and guide surgical planning, it is not required for initial management when the diagnosis is clinically confirmed.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical consultation is appropriate but not required immediately in Achilles tendon rupture. Decisions regarding definitive treatment can be made after initial immobilization and stabilization.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Initial management of Achilles tendon rupture involves immobilization with the foot in plantar flexion (using either a walking boot with heel lift or a posterior ankle splint), establishing non-weight-bearing status, and orthopedic referral. This immobilization reduces tension on the ruptured tendon and prevents further injury while awaiting definitive treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Weight-bearing as tolerated is inappropriate for acute Achilles tendon rupture. Non-weight-bearing status must be established to prevent further tendon injury and allow for proper healing.

E) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound is not necessary when the diagnosis is clinically confirmed with positive Thompson test and palpable tendon gap.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic with left ankle pain. He was playing basketball when he attempted a layup and felt a sudden, sharp pain in his lower leg, accompanied by an audible 'pop.' He describes a sensation of being kicked from behind. He has had difficulty bearing weight since the injury. On examination, there is moderate swelling and ecchymosis around the posterior ankle. A palpable defect is noted approximately 4 cm proximal to the calcaneal insertion. When the patient is prone, squeezing the gastrocnemius muscle belly fails to produce plantar flexion of the foot. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A gastrocnemius tear, or 'tennis leg,' can also manifest with a sudden pop and pain in the calf during athletic activity. However, the palpable defect and maximal tenderness would be located higher in the medial muscle belly. Although plantar flexion may be weak and painful, the Thompson test would typically still produce some movement of the foot.

B) INCORRECT:

Posterior tibial tendon dysfunction is usually a chronic, degenerative condition leading to an acquired flatfoot deformity. While an acute rupture can occur, it is less common and typically presents with pain and swelling along the medial aspect of the ankle, not the posterior midline. Moreover, the Thompson test would be negative.

C) INCORRECT:

A calcaneal stress fracture is an overuse injury, not an acute traumatic event. The onset of pain is typically gradual and worsens with weight-bearing activities like running. There would be no history of a sudden 'pop' or a palpable defect in the posterior tendon. Tenderness would be localized to the calcaneus itself, often elicited by squeezing the heel bone from both sides.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for an Achilles tendon rupture. The mechanism of injury involves sudden, forceful plantar flexion during an athletic activity. Patients typically report an audible 'pop' and a sensation of being kicked in the back of the leg. Key physical examination findings include a palpable defect in the tendon, typically in the watershed zone 2–6 cm proximal to the calcaneal insertion, and a positive Thompson test, which is highly specific for a complete rupture. Management can be either surgical or non-surgical, depending on patient factors.

E) INCORRECT:

A lateral ankle sprain is a common injury in basketball, but it results from an inversion mechanism, affecting the ligaments on the outside of the ankle. The pain, swelling, and ecchymosis would be centered over the lateral malleolus. The posterior calf would not be tender, there would be no palpable defect proximal to the calcaneal insertion, and the Thompson test would be negative.
questions.hint: The physical examination maneuver described, in which squeezing the calf muscle fails to produce foot movement (positive Thompson test), is a highly specific test for this type of injury.
